Background

Chronic cardiovascular disease (CVD) includes heart failure, coronary heart disease, stroke, peripheral artery disease, and aortic valve disease. It is the leading cause of fatal and non-fatal morbidity and mortality worldwide, with approximately 17.9 million people admitted as inpatients with CVD each year in the UK (1). In the UK, approximately 20% of adults aged 40-74 years and 40% of patients aged 75 years or more have CVD. Progression and severity of existing CVD is significantly higher in people with diabetes (T2DM) than in those without diabetes (2, 3). Both obesity (high BMI) and smoking are important independent risk factors for CVD (4, 5).

Guidance

Public Health England (PHE) has published draft guidance, ‘National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) CG188: Public Health Guidance: Type 2 diabetes in adults living in England' (6), which reviews the evidence on lifestyle-based interventions with the aim of preventing type 2 diabetes. The guidance suggests intervention before or at the point of diagnosis, along with lifestyle interventions for people with diagnosed T2DM and people at high risk of developing T2DM (based on either ethnicity or family history). While PHE’s guidance is relevant to individuals of Afro-Caribbean ethnicity because of their elevated risk of T2DM and CVD, it does not yet include guidelines for the management of cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention/management in people of Black ethnicity (7). This evidence brief outlines current best practice clinical guidance for the management of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in people of Black ethnicity living in England, with a focus on the following key points:

• Cardiovascular risk assessment

People of Black ethnicity (1) (7, 8) and T2DM (9, 10) have a greater risk of CVD and premature CVD events than people of White ethnicity, and the degree of risk increases over time if risk factors are not addressed. In addition, people of Black ethnicity may have lower levels of awareness of their CVD risk (1, 11) than people of other ethnic groups. Screening and early identification programmes based only on those people of White ethnicity risk factors may cause people of Black ethnicity to have unrecognised and unaddressed CVD risk factors. As such, it is important to assess the risk of CVD in all people aged over 40 years, or earlier in those with known T2DM/diabetes, and to make early referral to a CVD specialist for management if necessary.

In adults aged 40–74 years with a cardiovascular risk 10% or greater, NICE recommends that they are offered lifestyle advice (e.g. physical activity and a healthy diet). The 10% CVD risk points for people aged 18–39 years are not clearly set out within current UK public health guidelines. Further research is ongoing to establish the optimal age for cardiovascular risk assessment (12). However, cardiovascular risk assessment should begin from age 40 unless other CVD risk factors or CVD already exist.

The most basic CVD risk factor is coronary artery disease (CAD), which occurs in 4-6%. Because this CVD event requires cardiac, circulatory, and blood vessel function and is not specifically tied to smoking and other lifestyle factors, it is known to be highly dependent on CVD risk factors. Although smoking was thought to be the key driver of CAD, a recent systematic review of risk factors that included BMI and coronary artery mortality data (14, 25) found no association, with BMI being relatively lower among Caucasian, African, and Hispanics.

Cad risks associated with cigarette use were highly prevalent in general-aged adults (7.9%, 7.9%, 9.2%, and 13.5%, respectively), but non-pregnant women (4.5%, 4.8%, and 5.4%, respectively) were the only group suffering the highest risk of CAD. Adolescent smokers were 18 times more likely to have one or more cardiovascular events than women who consumed nicotine. Tobacco smoke exposure in childhood was higher for both smokers and nonsmokers than the risk associated with other tobacco smoking activities. Adolescent smokers had lower cholesterol and alcohol consumption rates and lower intakes of calcium and vitamin D; nonsmokers were 11 times more likely to smoke a variety of non-diarrheal drugs, such as vitamin D; and low-sugar, refined or over-the-counter cigarettes are less likely to be consumed over a period of 2 y than over a period of 4 y. These findings support the notion that smoking may be a key risk factor for CAD.

Many studies have suggested that smoking is often linked to increased risk of coronary disease (26, 27). In a study designed to provide support for the notion of smoking isomers in the CAD risk database that assessed the association between smoking status and the risk of a CAD event in 628 older adult participants, smoking was positively associated with a risk significantly higher than tobacco-related factors (29, 26). Thus, we hypothesized that smoking is a risk factor specifically for CAD. Additionally, we also hypothesized that these associations with cardiovascular risk and diabetes would be larger in older smokers than in younger smokers.

The association between smoking and risk of CAD was greatest in the period before 8 y when high consumption of cigarettes was inversely associated with an increased risk of CAD, whereas those who had never or who did not consume tobacco was associated with an increased risk of CAD in the second 12 y, but the higher risk was more pronounced in the 12-21 y follow-up period.
